title: Ancient Philosophers Quiz
description: Test your recall of the great thinkers who shaped Western philosophy!

questions.question: Which Greek philosopher was sentenced to death by drinking hemlock?
questions.explanation: Socrates was sentenced to death in 399 BC by an Athenian jury for impiety and corrupting the youth, and he drank hemlock poison.

questions.question: Who founded the Academy in Athens, one of the first institutions of higher learning?
questions.explanation: Plato founded the Academy in Athens around 387 BC, which continued to operate for nearly 900 years.

questions.question: Which philosopher was the tutor of Alexander the Great?
questions.explanation: Aristotle was hired by King Philip II of Macedon to tutor his son Alexander, who would later become Alexander the Great.

questions.question: Which philosopher is famous for saying 'I think, therefore I am'... wait, that was Descartes. Which ANCIENT philosopher said 'Know thyself'?
questions.explanation: While the phrase was inscribed at the Temple of Apollo at Delphi, it is most associated with Socrates and his philosophical method of self-examination.

questions.question: Which Greek philosopher believed everything was made of water?
questions.explanation: Thales of Miletus, often considered the first Western philosopher, proposed that water was the fundamental substance of the universe.

questions.question: Which philosopher lived in a barrel and carried a lantern searching for an honest man?
questions.explanation: Diogenes of Sinope was a famous Cynic philosopher known for his extreme lifestyle and provocative behavior.

questions.question: Which philosopher proposed the theory of atoms -- that all matter is made of indivisible particles?
questions.explanation: Democritus (c. 460-370 BC) developed the atomic theory, proposing that all matter consists of tiny indivisible particles called 'atomos.'

questions.question: Which philosopher founded Stoicism?
questions.explanation: Zeno of Citium founded the Stoic school of philosophy around 300 BC in Athens, teaching from the Stoa Poikile (Painted Porch).

questions.question: Which Roman Emperor was also a renowned Stoic philosopher who wrote 'Meditations'?
questions.explanation: Marcus Aurelius, Roman Emperor from 161 to 180 AD, wrote 'Meditations,' a series of personal philosophical reflections on Stoic philosophy.

questions.question: Which mathematician and philosopher is known for his theorem about right triangles?
questions.explanation: Pythagoras is famous for the Pythagorean theorem (a^2 + b^2 = c^2), though it may have been known earlier by Babylonian mathematicians.

questions.question: Which philosopher said 'No man ever steps in the same river twice'?
questions.explanation: Heraclitus of Ephesus emphasized constant change, famously stating that everything flows (panta rhei) and you cannot step in the same river twice.

questions.question: Which Roman philosopher and statesman wrote 'On the Nature of Things' about Epicurean philosophy?
questions.explanation: Lucretius wrote 'De Rerum Natura' (On the Nature of Things), a poem presenting the philosophy of Epicurus, including atomism and the mortality of the soul.

questions.question: Which philosopher founded a school called 'The Garden' and taught that pleasure was the highest good?
questions.explanation: Epicurus founded his school, called 'The Garden,' around 306 BC in Athens. He taught that the absence of pain and mental tranquility were the highest forms of pleasure.

questions.question: Which Chinese philosopher's teachings formed the basis of Confucianism?
questions.explanation: Confucius (Kong Qiu, 551-479 BC) was a Chinese philosopher whose teachings on ethics, family, and governance became the foundation of Confucianism.

questions.question: Which Roman Stoic philosopher was forced to commit suicide by Emperor Nero?
questions.explanation: Seneca the Younger, advisor to Emperor Nero, was ordered to commit suicide in 65 AD after being accused of involvement in a conspiracy against Nero.
